title-group.article-title: Who Gets Blamed for Intimate Partner Violence? The Relative Contributions of Perpetrator Sex Category, Victim Confrontation, and Observer Attitudes

author-notes.corresp: Cindy Stewart, Associate Professor of Psychology, Department of Social Sciences, University of Houston–Downtown, 1 Main Street, Suite N 1063, Houston, TX 77002, USA Email: StewartCi@uhd.edu

abstract.p: The present study examined the effects of perpetrator sex category, victim confrontation, observer sex category, and observer attitudes on attributions of blame and behavioral stability for partner violence. Data were collected from 728 college-aged students enrolled at 2 universities in the United States. Results demonstrated that males and females attributed less blame and behavioral stability to female perpetrators than male perpetrators, especially if the perpetrator was provoked. Moreover, attitudes toward women and violence were important for predicting attributions, and some of the evidence for observer effects was reduced to nonsignificance once these variables were added to the model.

body.p: More than 200 surveys of the general population demonstrate that the most commonly occurring pattern of intimate partner violence (IPV) is bidirectional violence or mutual battering (for meta-analytic reviews, see Archer, 2000; Fiebert, 2004) with females’ use of minor violence against males viewed as more acceptable than male’s use of minor violence against females (Douglas & Straus, 2006; Straus, 2009). Research shows that observers attribute blame for violent acts differently based on perpetrator sex category, victim confrontation, severity of the assault, and various observer characteristics. Thus, it is essential to explain the processes by which causal attributions for IPV are formed as there are implications for intervention, at both the individual and system level.

Attribution theory is used to understand how people form explanations for social psychological phenomena (Heider, 1958). With regard to IPV, attribution theory has been used to examine causal attributions for violent behavior. In such studies, the violent act is explicit and attributions of blame for the violent act are examined (Shaver & Drown, 1986). Less often examined in the IPV literature are attributions of behavioral stability, which examine if the violent act is perceived as situational or consistent. Foundational work in attribution theory demonstrates that attributions made about others’ traits (Heider, 1958; Mischel, 1968) and negative behaviors are considered stable (Furnham & Endler, 1982; Jones & McGillis, 1965). Argyle, Furnham, and Graham (1981) argued that attributions of behavioral stability aid in predicting patterns of social behavior and such attributions could affect IPV victims’ decisions to flee abusive relationships or jurors’ decisions in IPV cases at the punishment phase.

The general public views females as less violent than males (Straus, 2009) and that bias may influence attributions of culpability for females’ violent behaviors. Presumably, participants unintentionally ascribe sex-based traits to perpetrators and rely on those traits to comprehend violent acts (Winter & Uleman, 1984). In studies that have manipulated perpetrator sex category and attributions of blame, research shows that females are attributed less blame than males for similar violent acts (Bryant & Spencer, 2003; Cook & Harris, 1995; Esqueda & Harrison, 2005; Sorenson & Taylor, 2005) and victim confrontation yields more lenient punishment recommendations in the criminal justice system (Bradbury & Fincham, 1990). Taken together, females confronted by males are attributed the least amount of blame in comparison to females who were not confronted, or males who were confronted, and males not confronted by their female victims (Rhatigan, Stewart, & Moore, 2011; Sorenson & Taylor, 2005; Witte, Schroeder, & Lohr, 2006).

Culpability is influenced not only by perpetrator sex category but also by observer sex category, as males blame victims of IPV more than females (Bryant & Spencer, 2003; Lange & Knowles, 2000; Nayak, Byrne, Martin, & Abraham, 2003) and hold males less accountable for violent acts (Bryant & Spencer, 2003; Langhinrichsen-Rohling, Shlien-Dellinger, Huss, & Kramer, 2004; Pierce & Harris, 1993), whereas females attribute more blame to male perpetrators (Bryant & Spencer, 2003; Hamby & Jackson, 2010; Lange & Knowles, 2000; Kanekar, Pinto, & Mazumdar, 1985) and view violence as more deleterious (Koski & Manigold, 1988). Males are also more likely to attribute males’ violence to external/situational factors and attribute females’ violence to internal traits such as personality characteristics (Langhinrichsen-Rohling et al., 2004; Stamp & Sabourin, 1995). However, sex differences are found to be unreliable in some research areas (Unger, 1998; Yoder & Kahn, 2003) and reported sex differences could be conflated with other variables such as gender-related attitudes.

Typically, males hold more negative views of females than do females (Finn, 1986; Kristiansen & Guilietti, 1990; Spence, Helmreich, & Stapp, 1973), and such males blame female victims and hold male perpetrators less accountable for their violent behaviors (Hiller & Foddy, 1993; Howard, 1984a, 1984b). Moreover, males with traditional attitudes toward females and greater acceptance of violence are more likely to attribute blame to female rape victims (Caron & Carter, 1997) and have more positive perceptions of perpetrators of wife assault (Sugarman & Frankel, 1996).

The present study extends previous research by examining perpetrator sex category differences in attributions of blame and behavioral stability for IPV. The study used a quasi-experimental paradigm wherein hypothetical scenarios varied randomly by perpetrator sex category and confrontation level. Attitudes toward violence and women were examined for observer sex category differences. Based on previous research it was predicted that (a) male observers would attribute less blame and behavioral stability to male perpetrators who were confronted by their victims, (b) male observers with traditional views of females would attribute less blame and less behavioral stability to perpetrators than males with egalitarian attitudes toward females or female observers, and (c) male observers with accepting attitudes toward violence and traditional views of females would attribute less blame and less behavioral stability to male perpetrators than other observers.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: A total of 728 undergraduate students (449 female and 279 males) enrolled in psychology courses at one of two large, public, U.S., southern universities participated in this study for partial course credit or extra credit. Approval to conduct this research was granted by the institutional review boards at both institutions.

Demographic data showed that participants’ mean age was 20.3 years (SD = 2.4; range = 17-29) and that 54% were freshmen, 25% were sophomores, 14% were juniors, and 7% were seniors. Six ethnic groups were represented in the total sample: 55.6% were European American, 22.4% were Hispanic, 13.9% were African American, 2.7% were Asian American, 1.9% were Middle Eastern, 0.3% were Native American, and 3.0% were Other. Participants reflected the overall population of their respective universities.

sec.title: Design and Procedure
sec.p: Participants were randomly assigned to the female or male perpetrator and confrontation or no confrontation conditions and were directly assigned to the observer condition based on their sex category (female or male). Once the purpose of the study and general procedures were described and consent for participation was obtained, participants completed a demographics questionnaire, read one of the 4 randomly assigned vignettes that depicted conflict between male and female dating partners, and completed a series of other measures. Instructions were standardized and presentation of materials and order of the surveys remained consistent across data-collection sites.

sec.title: Hypothetical vignettes
sec.p: Four vignettes were constructed varying the sex category of the perpetrator (male or female perpetrator) and the level of confrontation (verbal confrontation or no confrontation) between male and female dating partners (see Table 1). Initial pilot work demonstrated that confrontation scenes were perceived as more “provocative” than the nonconfrontational scenes, F(3, 153) = 16.7, p < .001, with no differences for male and female perpetrators. In addition, there were no differences reported in terms of realism, F(3, 153) = 0.89, p = .45.

tr.td: You are returning home from a full day of classes when you notice your neighbors at their front door. In the past, you have heard a lot of screaming and yelling coming from their apartment, so you wait and listen. You overhear the girlfriend, Maria, telling her boyfriend, Robert, that some girl called for him and hung up before she could take a message. She then asks who the girl might have been. Robert says, “I am not sure. It might have been someone from class today.” She yells, “Drop the attitude! Tell me who the girl on the phone was or you’ll be really sorry.” You then witness Maria slap her boyfriend. Robert responds by holding his cheek, wincing in pain. Maria then yells, “You think that stings . . . Next time, it’ll really hurt!”

You are returning home from a full day of classes when you notice your neighbors at their front door. In the past, you have heard a lot of screaming and yelling coming from their apartment, so you wait and listen. You overhear the girlfriend, Maria, telling her boyfriend, Robert, that some girl called for him and hung up before she could take a message. She then asks who the girl might have been. Robert says, “Listen here, bitch (replaced with “bastard” in the male perpetrator/confrontational vignette), I told you never to answer my phone.” She yells, “Drop the attitude! Tell me who the girl on the phone was or you’ll be really sorry.” You then witness Maria slap her boyfriend. Robert responds by holding his cheek, wincing in pain. Maria then yells, “You think that stings . . . Next time, it’ll really hurt!”

You are returning home from a full day of classes when you notice your neighbors at their front door. In the past, you have heard a lot of screaming and yelling coming from their apartment, so you wait and listen. You overhear the boyfriend, Robert, telling his girlfriend, Maria, that some guy called for her and hung up before he could take a message. He then asks who the guy might have been. Maria says, “I am not sure. It might have been someone from class today.” He yells, “Drop the attitude! Tell me who the guy on the phone was or you’ll be really sorry.” You then witness Robert slap his girlfriend. Maria responds by holding her cheek, wincing in pain. Robert then yells, “You think that stings . . . Next time, it’ll really hurt!”

You are returning home from a full day of classes when you notice your neighbors at their front door. In the past, you have heard a lot of screaming and yelling coming from their apartment, so you wait and listen. You overhear the boyfriend, Robert, telling his girlfriend, Maria, that some guy called for her and hung up before he could take a message. He then asks who the guy might have been. Maria says, “Listen here, bastard, I told you never to answer my phone.” He yells, “Drop the attitude! Tell me who the guy on the phone was or you’ll be really sorry.” You then witness Robert slap his girlfriend. Maria responds by holding her cheek, wincing in pain. Robert then yells, “You think that stings . . . Next time, it’ll really hurt!”

sec.title: Demographics questionnaire
sec.p: A demographics questionnaire assessed sex category, age, academic level, and ethnicity.

sec.title: Attributions for violent behavior
sec.p: To assess attributions of causality, responsibility, and blame an 11-item measure based on well-established, relationship-related attribution measure (RAM; Fincham & Bradbury, 1992) and the theoretical notions distinguishing between causal, responsibility, and blaming attributions (Shaver & Drown, 1986) was constructed. Participants responded to the items using a 6-point Likert-type scale ranging from disagree strongly to agree strongly (see Rhatigan et al., 2011 for full measure). A principal components analysis with Varimax rotation was performed on the scale, and it yielded a two-factor solution. The first factor included five items that assessed blame and cause for the violent act, and the second factor included four items that examined behavioral stability. Two items failed to load on either factor and were excluded (see Table 2 for factor loadings and coefficient alpha values).

caption.p: Factor Loadings for Exploratory Factor Analysis for the Attributions for Violent Behavior Scale

tr.td: Perpetrator’s did not intend to harm victim
Perpetrator’s behavior is a onetime event
Perpetrator’s behavior is due to something about him or her

fn.p: Note: Coefficient alphas for the scales are as follows: Blame, α = .84; Behavioral Stability, α = .78.

sec.title: Attitudes toward violence
sec.p: The Velicer Attitudes toward Violence scale (VATVS; Velicer, Huckel, & Hansen, 1989) was used to measure attitudes toward violence in various forms. Sample items include “It is alright for a partner to slap another’s face if challenged” and “It is alright to coerce a partner into having sex when they are not willing by forcing them.” Participants responded using a 5-point Likert-type response format. Alpha coefficients for the five scales ranged from .74 to .90. Cronbach’s alpha was .76 in our sample.

sec.title: Attitudes toward women
sec.p: The Attitudes Toward Women–Short Version (AWS–Short version; Spence et al., 1973) was used to measure the extent to which individuals espouse either egalitarian or traditional views of women’s behavior in the workplace and at home; the short and long versions of the survey are almost perfectly correlated, r = .96 (see Spence et al., 1973). Daugherty and Dambrot (1986) assessed the reliability of the AWS scale; Cronbach’s alpha was .89 and the Spearman split-half reliability was .86. Cronbach’s alpha was .84 in our sample. Example items include the following: “The intellectual leadership of a community should be largely in the hands of men” and “A woman should be as free as a man to propose marriage.” Each item is accompanied by a 4-point response scale ranging from agree strongly to disagree strongly. Items are scored from 0 to 3; high scores indicate an egalitarian attitude.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Prior to conducting data analyses, patterns of missing data were explored using a linear interpolation method for imputing data for participants who completed at least 70% of items on the respective measures (for review, see Franke, 1982). Using this imputation method did not significantly change the results of the study, so we used the complete data set in all analyses.

To examine how men and women attribute blame and behavioral stability to violent perpetrators who were confronted by their victims, a factorial multivariate analysis of variance (MANOVA) was performed. The three-way interaction was not significant, but the interactions between perpetrator sex category and confrontation level, Λ = .98, F(2, 692) = 5.98, p < .01, ηp2 = .017, and perpetrator and observer sex category were significant, Λ = .99, F(2, 692) = 5.21, p < .01, ηp2 = .015. Multivariate main effects were found for perpetrator sex category, Λ = .86, F(2, 692) = 55.73, p < .0001, ηp2 = .139, confrontation level, Λ = .86, F(2, 692) = 56.51, p < .0001, ηp2 = .140, and observer sex category, Λ = .99, F(2, 692) = 4.70, p < .01, ηp2 = .013. Univariate effects for this analysis and further analyses are reported in Table 3.

caption.p: Univariate Effects for the Blame and Behavioral Stability Factors

fn.p: Note: Perp = perpetrator sex category, confront = confrontation level, observer = observer sex category, AWS = attitudes toward women, ATV = attitudes toward violence.

sec.p: Planned post hoc analyses demonstrated that women viewed female perpetrators’ violence as less stable than male perpetrators’ violence. Furthermore, male perpetrators who were not confronted by their victims were attributed more blame than were males who were confronted by their victims or female perpetrators. In addition, observers attributed more blame to male and female perpetrators as well as viewed violence as more stable in nonconfrontational scenarios. Male perpetrators were attributed more blame and viewed as engaging in more stable acts of violence than were female perpetrators, and females attributed more blame to violent perpetrators (male or female) than did males.

It was expected that attitudes toward women would influence attributions of blame and behavioral stability, and thus a factorial multivariate analysis of covariance (MANCOVA) was conducted, while holding significant interactions and main effects from the previous analysis constant. Results yielded a significant two-way multivariate interaction between observer sex category and attitudes toward women, Λ = .85, F(74, 1114) = 1.30, p < .01, ηp2 = .079, and significant multivariate main effects for attitudes toward women, Λ = .78, F(90, 1114) = 1.63, p < .0001, ηp2 = .116, and the covariates confrontation by perpetrator sex category, perpetrator by observer sex category, and confrontation, Λ = .97, F(2, 557) = 7.54, p < .0001, ηp2 = .026, Λ = .99, F(2, 557) = 3.94, p < .01, ηp2 = .014, Λ = .97, F(2, 557) = 8.17, p < .0001, ηp2 = .028, respectively.

Tukey’s honestly significant difference (HSD) revealed that males with traditional views of women attributed less behavioral stability to violent male and female perpetrators. In addition, observers with traditional attitudes toward women attributed less blame and behavioral stability to violent perpetrators than did participants with egalitarian views of women. Moreover, females attributed greater behavioral stability to male perpetrators, and observers (females and males) attributed less blame when the victim was confrontational.

It was also predicted that males with greater acceptance of violence and traditional views of women would lead to lesser assignment of blame and behavioral stability to male perpetrators. A factorial MANCOVA yielded significant multivariate three-way interactions between attitudes toward violence, attitudes toward women, and observer sex category, Λ = .81, F(182, 330) = 1.42, p < .01, ηp2 = .438, and attitudes toward violence, attitudes toward women, and perpetrator sex category, Λ = .36, F(414, 330) = 1.44, p < .0001, ηp2 = .400. The two-way multivariate interaction was significant for attitudes toward women by attitudes toward violence, Λ = .60, F(167, 330) = 1.41, p < .001, ηp2 = .162, as were the covariate effects for perpetrator sex category and confrontation level, Λ = .80, F(2, 165) = 21.27, p < .0001, ηp2 = .205, Λ = .81, F(2, 165) = 19.59, p < .0001, ηp2 = .192, respectively.

Planned post hoc analyses revealed that men with accepting attitudes toward violence and traditional views of women viewed violent acts as unstable and men and women with traditional views of women and greater acceptance of violence blamed female perpetrators more than male perpetrators for similar acts of violence. Moreover, observers with egalitarian attitudes toward women and who were less accepting of violence viewed violence as more unstable.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The purpose of the present study was to examine the impact of theoretically derived predictors of blame and behavioral stability attributions for male and female perpetrated IPV. Much like previous research, which asserts that attributions are multidimensional (e.g., internal/external, temporary/stable, positive/negative), we found that attributions of blame and behavioral stability are separate constructs when evaluating violent acts and particular information is central in making such attributions.

There were clear and consistent differences in attributions of blame and behavioral stability for male- and female-perpetrated violence among our participants, with male perpetrators attributed more blame and behavioral stability. Not surprisingly, these data are consistent with past research (e.g., Ferguson & Negy, 2004; Sorenson & Taylor, 2005) and suggest that most participants differentially respond to a male’s use of violence. Consistent with gendered views of violent behavior, males are often viewed as aggressors in IPV, and thus males and females may attribute males’ behaviors to dispositional traits rather than situational factors. Conversely, people may assume that violent acts are out of character for females and must be explained by other situational variables such as self-defensive (Saunders, 2002).

Research on the consequences of violence suggest that males’ violence tends to be perceived as more harmful (Stith, Smith, Penn, Ward, & Tritt, 2004) with females incurring more injuries (e.g., Archer, 2000). Thus, the public may be fairly accurate in their reasons for differentially perceiving males’ and females’ violence. It remains to be seen whether the impact of violence on the victim ought to be considered in the determination of culpability, though current data suggest that it often is (Sorenson & Taylor, 2005).

Beyond the impact of violence, people may also believe that males and females possess different motivations for violence, with males using violence to control and females using violence to self-protect (Felson & Messner, 2000; Saunders, 2002; Stuart et al., 2006). Different motivations are likely to contribute to the public’s assessment of blame and whether a perpetrator’s violence is unremitting. Future studies might consider examining other contextual factors such as perpetrator motivation for violence and/or the impact of the violence (e.g., fear or injury) as additional predictors of attributions for violent events.

Increased attributions of blame for male perpetrators were compounded when they were not confronted by their female victims. Overall, participants attributed less blame and behavioral stability to cases of violence involving victim confrontation as compared to those involving no confrontation. These findings are consistent with past research showing that people, in general, believe that provocative victims should be held partially to blame for their attacks (Sorenson & Taylor, 2005) and perpetrators’ use of violence against confrontational victims should be shown greater leniency (Bradbury & Fincham, 1990). Situational variables seem to be important contextual factors influencing fault and behavioral stability attributions as demonstrated in studies examining other situational characteristics, such as victim alcohol consumption or infidelity (Sorenson & Taylor, 2005).

Males and females differ in their attributions for violent acts and those differences may best be understood in terms of gender-related attitudes. Males who are more accepting of violence and hold traditional attitudes of women attribute less behavioral stability to violent perpetrators. In addition, participants who have traditional views of women and are more accepting of violence attribute more blame to female perpetrators, a finding consistent with Howard (1984a, 1984b). Traditionalists view the normal female as “weak,” and thus females are at a double disadvantage when they fail to conform to stereotypes by either being a confrontational victim or an aggressor (e.g., Mugford, 1989). In fact, males and females with traditional attitudes toward women attribute less blame for violent acts and view violence as more situational than do those with egalitarian views of women. Furthermore, males and females who are more accepting of violence view violent behavior as less stable.

Strengths and limitations of the present study should be noted. The lack of institutional differences increases generalizability. However, we collected data from a convenient sample of college students, and thus our findings may not necessarily generalize to a community or national sample of males and females. Though, in this regard, our findings are consistent with a study that used a large community sample (Sorenson & Taylor, 2005). As for limitations, our study employed the use of one vignette rather than multiple scenes and did not assess attributions regarding severe forms of violence, particularly those using a weapon. It may be that in cases where females have access to and use a weapon, such as a gun, all biases disappear since presumably size and strength in such circumstances should not matter (see as example, Sorenson & Taylor, 2005).

sec.title: Implications and Conclusions
sec.p: The public is more accepting of a female’s use of force against a male intimate partner relative to a male’s use of force against a female intimate partner. In many ways, intolerant responses to males’ violence may be beneficial to society as this suggests that IPV is no longer seen as a “private family matter.” In contrast, however, societal tolerance of females’ violence may possibly be problematic in that it may partially explain current prevalence rates of mutual IPV (e.g., Archer, 2000).

Others might rationalize that the prevalence rates are a function of males’ violence against females and females’ needs to defend themselves against their violent attackers. From this point of view, unlike males, females’ use of force is situational and not dispositional. Although females are increasingly being arrested and adjudicated for IPV (Hamberger & Potente, 1994), convicted females’ overwhelming reported use of violence in self-defense (see DeKeseredy, Saunders, Schwartz, & Alvi, 1997) provides further support to the notion that violent females are less likely to be repeat offenders and thus not deserving of severe sentences. However, when females fail to conform to stereotypes held by those with traditional views of women, they may be likely to be penalized for violation of gender norms, such as in the case of victim confrontation, where blame and behavioral stability are defused across the perpetrator and victim. For these reasons, the problem of females’ violence needs to be considered, evaluated, and better understood.

fn.label: Authors’ Note
fn.p: This article is dedicated to Deborah L. Rhatigan, who passed away in December 2009 after a long battle with cancer. She was a thoughtful and meticulous researcher, who was devoted to ensuring that her work positively affected battered women.

fn.label: Declaration of Conflicting Interests
fn.p: The author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: The author(s) received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

bio.title: Bios
bio.p: Cindy Stewart, PhD, is a tenured associate professor at the University of Houston–Downtown. She received her doctoral degree in developmental psychology from the University of Houston. Her primary research interests include alcohol use and intimate partner violence.

Todd Moore, PhD, is a tenure-track assistant professor at the University of Tennessee. He received his doctoral degree from Virginia Tech and completed a postdoctoral research fellowship at the Brown University Center for alcohol and addiction studies. His research interests include examining the association between substance use and intimate partner violence as well as examining risk factors for relapse using electronic diary technology.

Travis Crone, PhD, is a tenure-track assistant professor at the University of Houston–Downtown. He received his doctoral degree from the University of Arkansas. His current research interests include nonconscious goal structures and the role of causal attributions in decision making and attitude change.

Stacie Craft DeFreitas, PhD, is a tenure-track assistant professor at the University of Houston–Downtown. She received her doctoral degree in clinical psychology from Duke University. Her primary research interests include the academic and mental health outcomes of youth, particularly, ethnic minority ones.

Deborah Rhatigan, PhD, was a tenure-track assistant professor at the University of Tennessee–Knoxville. She received her doctoral degree in clinical psychology from Virginia Tech and completed her postdoctoral research at the National Center for Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) in Boston, Massachusetts. Her primary research interests centered on abused women’s stay/leave decision-making processes. She passed away in December 2009, but her research will continue to positively influence the lives of battered women.
